anchor.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a piece of heavy metal that is lowered to the bottom of the sea, a lake etc to prevent a ship or boat moving
anchor.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: We dropped anchor a few yards offshore.
The next morning, they weighed anchor  (=lifted the anchor) and began to move south again.
anchor.translation[0].definitions[1].def: someone who reads the news on TV and introduces news reports
anchor.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Dan Rather, anchor of the CBC Evening News
anchor.translation[0].definitions[2].def: someone or something that provides a feeling of support and safety
anchor.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Dad was the anchor of the family.
anchor.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to lower the anchor on a ship or boat to hold it in one place
anchor.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Three tankers were anchored in the harbor.
anchor.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to fasten something firmly so that it cannot move
anchor.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The shelves should be securely anchored to the wall.
anchor.translation[1].definitions[1].not: Anchor is usually passive in this meaning
anchor.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to provide a feeling of support, safety, or help for someone or an organization
anchor.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Her life was anchored by her religion.
anchor.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to be the person who reads the news and introduces reports on television
